descriptions.1: So far we've been comparing values explicitly, like 'if name != ""'. Python actually gives us a shorter way to write these checks using a concept called truthiness (technically boolean coercion). We'll explore that in this lesson.
descriptions.2: Here we check if 'name' has a value using an explicit comparison to "". Python gives us a more concise way to write this — any non-empty string is considered truthy, meaning it behaves like True in a boolean context. So 'if name != ""' can be written simply as 'if name'.
descriptions.3: Your turn. Practice writing a truthy check with a hardcoded non-empty string.
descriptions.4: Now the flip side. An empty string "" is considered falsy — it behaves like False. So instead of 'if name == ""' we can use the 'not' keyword to negate the truthy value: 'if not name'.
descriptions.5: Your turn. Practice writing a negated truthy check with a hardcoded empty string.
descriptions.6: Now let's apply this in a realistic context. We'll get a name from the user and use a guard clause — a check that catches invalid input early and handles it before the rest of the program runs.
descriptions.8:
Let's review:
1) Any non-empty string is truthy — it behaves like True.
2) An empty string is falsy — it behaves like False.
3) We can use this to write cleaner conditions without explicit comparisons to "".
4) A guard clause uses a negated truthy check to catch invalid input early.

instructions.3: Write an if statement that prints 'Hello, Alice!' if name is truthy. Use the variable name in the condition, not an explicit comparison.
instructions.5: Write an if statement that prints 'No name entered.' if name is falsy. Use the 'not' keyword in the condition.
instructions.7: Write the guard clause condition to check if name is empty using a truthy check.
